summary: Mathilda (Natalie Portman) is only 12 years old, but is already familiar with the dark side of life: her abusive father stores drugs for corrupt police officers, and her mother neglects her. Léon (Jean Reno), who lives down the hall, tends to his houseplants and works as a hired hitman for mobster Tony (Danny Aiello). When her family is murdered by crooked DEA agent Stansfield (Gary Oldman), Mathilda joins forces with a reluctant Léon to learn his deadly trade and avenge her family's deaths.

reviews.content: While it occasionally lacks persistence and imminence, Leon: The Professional is an assertive, manful and well-scripted action-thriller with a sturdy juxtaposition and a cleverly handled, on pair chemistry between Jean Reno and Natalie Portman.

Luc Besson's film Leon:The Professional is a superb one. Visually, it is very stylish, with striking location work, atmospheric lighting and really authentic and bold cinematography. The soundtrack also does very well in enhancing the mood of each scene, and Besson's direction is faultless.

There is also a gripping story with well crafted characters particularly Mathilda and Jean Reno's character Leon, a cracking script and crisp pacing and while there are some over-the-top and intense moments particularly with Stansfield and the beginning, particularly as the chemistry between Mathilda and Leon expands there are some poignant ones too.

The acting is excellent. Jean Reno is charismatic and commanding in the title role while Gary Oldman is wildly bombastic as Stansfield. But I was especially impressed by Natalie Portman, who delivers one of the best and most captivating feature debuts ever. In conclusion, a fantastic film. 10/10 Bethany Cox

I watched the extended version, and it was incredible. The characters are so vibrant and full of life, all very different from each other. It seems as if each individual in the story has their own motivations, there are no true united factions. The dynamics between Mathilda and Léon are very well written - to me, not very creepy. Yes, Mathilda is always seeking to get a sexual rise out of Léon, but she is not acting like a thirty-year-old prostitute or something, it really seems like she is a twelve year old who doesn't know what she's asking for, and Léon seems like he recognizes this, and never entertains Mathilda's propositions or temptations. Elsewhere, Stansfield is a very well written character; the only thing that that screamed 'this is a movie' about him to me was his weird spasms whenever he took those pills. Tony was much too honorable, likable, and honest for a hit-brokering mafioso. The action scenes were very entertaining, and the choreography of Léon's moves was intuitive, if unrealistic. I liked the character's wardrobes (I don't understand people who say Mathilda is dressed inappropriately for a twelve-year-old). Overall, a must-watch. Fantastic film.

A dark, wild, and extremely emotional cinematic masterpiece, "Léon: The Professional" stands as a showcase of its phenomenal cast and the creative mind of Luc Besson. The unique and different plot is handled very well, resulting in an emotionally powerful and incredibly moving story. The action is also done very well, though I think the film is strongest during its more dramatic heart-to-heart moments. The acting is fantastic from the whole cast, though Oldman and Portman shine among all the others. The characters are also done very well and are extremely memorable, with each of the three main characters having their own time to shine. My only real issue is the odd romance that was injected for absolutely no reason, which made the film extremely uncomfortable to watch at certain parts. Ignoring that major flaw, however, I did really like the movie and think it stands as one of the better action movies made.

On paper, Leon: The Professional sounds like any other film centered around a hitman – action, killings and plenty of assorted violence.  Thanks to Luc Besson's creative direction and interesting characters, Leon: The Professional is a cut way above the rest.  Leon (Jean Reno) is the soft-spoken but deadly "cleaner", a cold-blooded killer with a strict code of ethics.  Mathilda is the twelve-year old neighbor whose dysfunctional family has been killed as the result of a drug dispute by a corrupt cop (Gary Oldman).  The three main characters all have a depth that far exceeds that of characters in similar films in the genre.   But it's Besson's direction that truly impresses.  Filled with interesting shots, perfect blocking and probing camerawork, Leon: The Professional is clearly superior to the typical Hollywood cookie cutter thriller.

Luc Besson's indie crime drama Leon: The Professional (1994) remains the French auteur's greatest picture by far. His focused and expressive French direction alongside cinematographer Thierry Arbogast's stunning, long held close-ups and creative wide shots during the action shootouts ensure that Leon is awe inspiring for future audiences forevermore. I must mention that although Luc Besson is a wretched creep as a man, he managed to use up all his creative powers to write and direct one of cinema's finest pictures.

Besson's writing is both creatively playful with funny dialogue and one liners, while also leaving you in despair at all the suffering and loneliness in Leon. His original story full of shocking brutality, clever wit, kind acts, and breathtaking twists result in Leon's memorable experience.

Eric Serra's score is riveting with gentle melodies and tight, anxiety inducing throbs of sound for the hail of bullets during the action sequences. Sylvie Landra's editing is sharp and tight, keeping Leon at a brisk 111 minutes that never feels long. Magali Guidasci's costumes are fun with Gary Oldman's white suit, Leon's all black hitman gear and vest, and of course, Natalie Portman's silly 90's kid outfits.

Jean Reno is so sensitive and subtle as the reserved assassin for hire Leon Montana. He's very playful and fatherly towards Mathilda Lando, saving Leon: The Professional's relationship with the young girl he saves from ever truly feeling gross. Natalie Portman is amazing for a child actress as the precocious child hitwoman protege Mathilda. She's funny, devastating, fearful, lonely, and a myriad of other emotions in a realistic flurry of acting prowess. 

Then, Gary Oldman is hilarious and terrifying as the crooked DEA agent Norman Stansfield. His campy drug addiction meets Oldman's gripping nightmare presence as the erratic and trigger happy Norman at his absolute scariest during the bathroom scene with Mathilda. Danny Aiello is excellent and enjoyable as the mob boss Tony with a nice rapport with Reno.

In short, Leon: The Professional is as fun and entertaining as action thriller films get, but Luc Besson's visionary direction and refreshing script keep Leon and Mathilda in your heart always.

Leon the Professional sets itself apart as one of the most unique action movies. This movie is a beautiful tragedy. Instead of focusing on moments of masculinity and testosterone, Leon focuses on the vulnerability of their protagonists with depth, heart and a sense of love and decency, a rarity explored in the action genre. Natalie Portman has a fantastic debut as a vengeful orphan; Jean Reno plays a surprisingly vulnerable and lonely assassin; but Gary Oldman is utterly brilliant in his performance as one of my favorite villains as a chaotic evil disguised as an orderly evil. The action is top-notched and gritty, with an emphasis on more of how the main character, Leon, acts as a contrast as a cold assassin on the job than in his quiet life. But it all comes ahead in a third act that is emotionally gut-runching when those two lives cross perpendicular. Leon the Professional is an awesome movie that is worth a watch.

Despite his excellence, Natalie Portman outshined everyone, even Reno, in her role as Mathilda, a revenge-seeking girl that has to grow up before she's ready. She leaves such an impact from the way she harbors rage and sadness, sometimes within the same scene. While young, this is also one of her strongest performances as an actress. When you're getting the best of your two stars, you know you have a great movie on your hands.

Beginning: 10

Characters: 10

Cinematography/Visuals: 8

Conflict: 7
I think my issue with the actual conflict throughout the duration of the movie stems more from how amazing the beginning is. The first ten minutes of the movie almost spoil you into expecting the rest of the film to be that way. Alas it is not. It moves at a bit of a slower clip and you start to feel it playing out as more of a drama than an action movie. Don't get me wrong, there is plenty of tension to be had, just not quite enough to blow me away.

Entertainment Value: 8

Memorability: 7
There is one particularly tense moment that had my heart racing: I don't want to give too much away by setting the scene, but Mathilda is waiting outside of Leon's door, pleading for him to let her in. Every single time I watch that scene, my heart leaps into my throat even though I know what's going to happen. It's that intense vulnerability that really sticks out. While the movie isn't oozing with scenes to remember, say like my last review of Dirty Dancing, there was definitely enough to keep my attention.

Pace: 10
Once you understand that the movie is a drama and not an action film, you can respect the pace a lot more. The movie pushes character development and the relationship between Leon and Mathilda. By the time the film reaches its conclusion, there is legitimate concern for their well-being because you've grown to like both of them.

Léon: The Professional is a 1994 mystery drama directed by Luc Besson. The film stars Jean Reno as Léon and Natalie Portman as Mathilda.

The story wasn't what I'd call exemplary by any means, but it did keep me engaged and intrigued from start to finish with no problems.

The cast featuring Jean Reno, Natalie Portman, Gary Oldman, Danny Aiello, Michael Badalucco and Peter Appel all did a very good job at portraying their characters; from Jean Reno's threatening but charming performance to Gary Oldman's notable portrayal of Norman Stansfield. 

The characters I found to be really charming and enjoyable; from the believable chemistry between Léon and Mathilda to the odd but sinister Norman Stansfield.

The cinematography I found to be quite strong, giving us some very stylish and memorable shots.

The action scenes were both thrilling and enjoyable, giving us some violent, but comical kills. The action scenes were also shot and directed very well, with some particularly strong practical effects that helped bring out the comical style of the violence.

The soundtrack I found fit the tone of the film perfectly; from the great instrumentals to the overall good vibes it gave off.

The film also had some pretty good comedic moments here and there, especially between Léon and Mathilda.

The film had a very atmospheric but (for the most part) light-hearted presence to it, particularly with the relationship between Léon and Matilda in the second act.

The film I found to be very engaging and entertaining, and I can't wait to watch it again.

Overall I give it a
8/10 - really strong film, would definitely recommend
